importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The incident occurred early Monday, October 19, 2025, at Hong Kong International Airport, marking a significant event in aviation safety and operations.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The incident occurred around 3:50 a.m. local time, which is during early morning hours, when airport operations are typically less busy, making the skid off the runway particularly concerning.

keyTakeAways: A cargo plane operated by ACT Airlines skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport and crashed into the sea, killing two airport staff in a vehicle it struck.
The Boeing aircraft, arriving from Dubai, broke in two upon impact, with the tail section snapped off and significant damage to the front section below the cockpit.
The four crew members were treated for injuries and confirmed to be safe; no cargo was on board.
The aircraft did not transmit any distress signals during approach, indicating a possible failure in control or runway handling.
The airport suspended operations on its north runway temporarily due to the wreckage, but two other runways remain operational, minimizing flight disruptions.
The flight was wet-leased from ACT Airlines, which provides cargo capacity to major airlines like Emirates.
Despite Hong Kong being one of the world’s busiest airports, fatal aviation accidents are rare, though this incident highlights operational risks.
The airport has a history of aviation safety concerns, including a major crash in 1999 involving a China Airlines flight during a typhoon.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A cargo plane operated by Turkish cargo carrier ACT Airlines skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport during arrival from Dubai around 3:50 a.m. local time, breaking in two and crashing into the sea. The aircraft struck an airport security patrol car, killing two occupants. The four crew members were injured but treated and released. Despite no distress signals being sent, the incident caused significant damage to the aircraft, prompting a large emergency response involving over 200 people, fire engines, and boats. The airport temporarily suspended operations on its north runway, though other runways remain operational, minimizing flight disruptions. The flight was wet-leased from ACT Airlines, which provides cargo capacity to major airlines like Emirates. This event, though rare at Hong Kong’s busy airport, reflects ongoing safety challenges, especially considering the historical context of past aviation incidents at the region’s former Kai Tak Airport.
title: Two killed as cargo plane skids off runway into the sea in Hong Kong
